medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Acute appendicitis. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Ruptured appendicitis. PROCEDURE: Laparoscopic appendectomy. INDICATIONS FOR PROCEDURE: This patient is a 4-year-old boy with less than 24-hour history of apparent right lower quadrant abdominal pain associated with vomiting and fevers. The patient has elevated white count on exam and CT scan consistent with acute appendicitis. DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The patient was taken to the operating room, placed supine, put under general endotracheal anesthesia. The patient's abdomen was prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion. A periumbilical incision was made. The fascia was incised. Peritoneal cavity entered bluntly. A 10-mm trocar and scope was passed. Peritoneal cavity was insufflated. Five-mm ports placed in left lower and hypogastric areas. On visualization of the right lower quadrant, appendix was visualized stuck against the right anterior abdominal wall, there is obvious site of perforation and leakage of content and pus. We proceeded to take the mesoappendix down to the base, and once the base was free, we placed GIA stapler across the base, fired the stapler, removed the appendix through the periumbilical port site. We irrigated and suctioned out the right lower and pelvic areas. We then removed the ports under direct visualization, closed the periumbilical port site fascia with 0 Vicryl, all skin incisions with 5-0 Monocryl, and dressed with Steri-Strips. The patient was extubated in the operating table and taken back to recovery room. The patient tolerated the procedure well.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Acute appendicitis.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Ruptured appendicitis.  

PROCEDURE: Laparoscopic appendectomy.  

INDICATIONS FOR PROCEDURE: A 4‑year‑old boy has been in pain in the lower right side of his belly for less than 24 hours, with vomiting and fever. His blood test shows a high white‑blood‑cell count and a CT scan confirms an inflamed appendix.  

DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The boy was taken to the operating room and laid on his back. He was put under general anesthesia through a breathing tube. His belly was cleaned and covered with sterile drapes. A small incision was made around the belly button. The muscle layer was cut open and the belly cavity was entered gently. A 10‑mm camera and tube were inserted, and the cavity was inflated with gas. Two additional 5‑mm tubes were placed in the lower left and lower front areas. When the surgeon looked at the lower right side, the appendix was seen stuck to the front wall of the belly, with a clear hole and leaking pus. The surgeon cut the tissue that connects the appendix to the blood supply down to the base. Once the base was free, a stapling device was placed across it, fired, and the appendix was removed through the belly‑button incision. The surgeon washed and suctioned the lower right and pelvic areas. The tubes were removed while watching the inside of the belly. The belly‑button incision was closed with 0 Vicryl for the muscle layer and 5‑0 Monocryl for the skin, and covered with Steri‑Strips. The boy was taken off the breathing tube in the operating room and sent to recovery. He tolerated the surgery well.
